questions.text: Down syndrome patients are found to have a reduced life expectancy compared to the general population. Which among the following is considered the chief cause of mortality especially in the first decade of life?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The chief cause of early mortality in Down Syndrome patients is Congenital Heart Disease. Furthermore, Endocardial Cushion Defects (ECDs) are the most common congenital heart disease in patients with Down Syndrome.
  • Atrioventricular septal defect (AVSD) is the most common type. If not repaired early, it can lead to heart failure, pulmonary hypertension, and early mortality. The current average life expectancy in Down Syndrome is 50-55 years.

Key features of Down's syndrome include:

  • Brachycephaly : Flattened skull
  • Mongloid slant of eyes: Lateral canthus placed higher than the medial canthus
  • Brushfield spots in iris
  • Flat nasal bridge
  • Low-set ears
  • Congenital heart disease: Most common is Endocardial cushion defect
  • GIT abnormalities: Duodenal atresia
  • Lukemias: ALL, while most specific is AML-M7. It causes mortality in the later childhood not in the first decade of life.(Option C ruled out)
  • Hands show: simian crease(single transverse palmar crease) and clinodactyly
  • Feet show: Sandals gap(wide gap between 1st and 2nd toe)
  • Atlantoaxial Instability: Increased risk of cervical spine injury, but symptomatic spinal cord compression is rare and not a direct leading cause for mortality.(Option D ruled out)
  • Low IQ and high risk of alzheimer disease(APP gene present on chromosome 21)
  • Obesity
  • High risk of hypothyroidism
  • Undescended testis
  • Early onset Alzheimer's disease

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in Down Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Caudal Regression Syndrome (CRS), also called as Sacral Agenesis, is rare in general population, but more common in infants of diabetic mothers (specific for these babies). It has not been described in Down Syndrome.

Explanation of other options:

  • Short stature (Option B): Linear growth is retarded in Down Syndrome
  • Hypothyroidism (Option C): especially congenital or acquired autoimmune thyroiditis is very common in Down syndrome.
  • Conductive hearing loss (Option D):Due to midface hypoplasia, narrow ear canals, and frequent otitis media, conductive hearing loss is common.

questions.text: Down syndrome children have a decreased risk of developing the following as compared to the general population?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Most Down Syndrome children have a positive association (increased risk) of problems like low IQ, early-onset Alzheimer's Disease, leukemias, Celiac disease, duodenal atresia etc.
  • However, there are certain conditions, whose risk is lower in Down Syndrome compared to the general population. Such association is called Protective or Negative Association.
  • The conditions which are less prevalent in Down syndrome than general population include
    • Solid pediatric tumours like Neuroblastoma & Wilms Tumour
    • Epithelial tumours in adults
    • Ischemic heart disease.

Explanation of other options:

  • Alzheimer Disease (Option A): Individuals with Down syndrome are at significantly increased risk of developing early-onset Alzheimer disease, often by age 40-50.
  • This is due to overexpression of the amyloid precursor protein (APP) gene located on chromosome 21.
  • Leukemia (Option C): Children with Down syndrome have a 15-20 times higher risk of developing leukemia, especially:
    • Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL)
    • Acute Megakaryoblastic Leukemia (AMKL) (particularly in infants and toddlers)
  • Celiac Disease(Option D): Down syndrome is associated with autoimmune conditions, including celiac disease. Routine screening is recommended.

questions.text: A newborn is noted to have multiple congenital anomalies including hypoplastic ribs, midline scalp defects, cleft palate, rocker-bottom feet, closely spaced eyes, and holoprosencephaly. These findings are most characteristic of which chromosomal disorder?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Trisomy 13 (Patau Syndrome) is a chromosomal disorder caused by an extra copy of chromosome 13. It is characterized by multiple severe congenital anomalies like :
    • Scalp defects (e.g., cutis aplasia)
    • Microphthalmia, corneal abnormalities
    • Cleft lip and palate in 60%-80% of cases
    • Microcephaly
    • Microphthalmia
    • Sloping forehead
    • Holoprosencephaly (arhinencephaly)
    • Capillary hemangiomas
    • Deafness
    • Cong heart disease
    • Missing ribs
    • Polydactyly
    • Hypoplastic and Hyperconvex nails

Explanation of other options:

  • Trisomy 21 (Down Syndrome)(Option A):
    Common features include upslanting palpebral fissures, epicanthal folds, flat nasal bridge, intellectual disability, and a single palmar crease. Not associated with holoprosencephaly or scalp defects.
  • Trisomy 22(Option B):
    Rare and typically incompatible with life beyond infancy.
  • Trisomy 18 (Edwards Syndrome)(Option C): Features include micrognathia, clenched fists with overlapping fingers, rocker-bottom feet, congenital heart defects, and prominent occiput but not holoprosencephaly or scalp defects, which help differentiate it from Trisomy 13.

Key Takeaways:

  • Rocker-bottom feet are more commonly seen in Edward Syndrome, but have also been described sometimes in Patau Syndrome.
  • However, Cleft palate, Scalp defects & Cleft lip/palate are very specific for Patau Syndrome.

questions.text: A baby was born with a small but elongated skull, omphalocele, VSD, overlapping fingers, tight palpebral fissures, micrognathia and rocker bottom feet. Which among the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A baby with features of elongated skull, omphalocele, VSD, overlapping fingers, tight palpebral fissures, micrognathia and rocker bottom feet is suggestive of Edward Syndrome (Trisomy 18).

Features of Edward's syndrome

questions.text: A male child with webbed neck and facial dysmorphism was found to have PTPN-11 gene mutation. Which of the following are not likely to be seen in this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical picture given in the scenario is suggestive of Noonan Syndrome.
  • Noonan syndrome is a common autosomal dominant disorder characterized by short stature, congenital heart disease,hypogonadism and mildly dysmorphic features. Feeding problems may result in failure to thrive and short stature.(Option A , Option B and Option D ruled out)
  • Mild developmental delays are often present, but intelligence may be normal.
  • Noonan syndrome and Noonan-like disorders are caused by mutations in the RAS-mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway, and thus are often called as "RASopathies." Noonan syndrome is the most common of these disorders, usually caused by mutations in PTPN-11.
  • Noonan syndrome is often referred to as "male Turner syndrome" because of overlapping features like:
    • Short stature
    • Webbed neck
    • Congenital heart disease
  • But genetically, Noonan syndrome individuals have a normal karyotype (usually 46,XY in males), unlike Turner syndrome (45,X).
  • Cubitus varus is the least likely finding among the given options and thus the correct answer.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl with Down syndrome presents for her annual check-up. She had a VSD repaired at 7 months and has been doing well since. Her mother reports she is thriving in kindergarten. On examination, you note her height has dropped to the 10th percentile (from the 25th) and her weight has increased to the 75th percentile (from the 50th). What is the next logical step in her evaluation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the given clinical scenario a drop in height percentile with a disproportionate increase in weight (rising BMI) is a classic early clue of hypothyroidism.
  • Children with Down syndrome are at increased risk for developing hypothyroidism and require regular screening.
  • This could account for decrease in height percentile with increased weight.
  • Celiac disease generally would cause poor weight gain.
  • Cushing syndrome could cause weight gain with poor growth, but this is less common than hypothyroidism. GH deficiency also can cause these findings but is not as common as hypothyroidism.(Option B,Option C,Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaway:

  • In a child with Down syndrome and growth deceleration, always first rule out hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A term, appropriate-for-gestational-age female infant is noted at birth to have webbed neck and lymphedema of the feet. Karyotype analysis reveals a normal 46,XX chromosomal pattern. Which of the following conditions should still be considered in the differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Turner syndrome classically presents with webbed neck and peripheral lymphedema at birth, but is associated with a 45,X karyotype (monosomy X). However, in a phenotypic female with normal 46,XX chromosomes, the next most likely cause of Turner-like features is Noonan syndrome.
  • Noonan syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder that can occur in both males and females, and is often referred to as the "male Turner phenotype."
  • Characteristic features include:
    • Webbed neck
    • Lymphedema of hands/feet
    • Short stature
    • Congenital heart defects (commonly pulmonary valve stenosis)
    • Facial dysmorphism (hypertelorism, ptosis, down-slanting palpebral fissures)
  • Karyotype is typically normal (46,XX or 46,XY), and diagnosis is clinical or confirmed by genetic testing for mutations like PTPN11.

Explanation of other options:

  • Fetal Alcohol syndrome(Option A): Patients with fetal alcohol syndrome have normal karyotype with distinct facial features including wide set eyes, microcephaly, and smooth philtrum.
  • Down syndrome(Option C): Patients with Down syndrome have an extra chromosome 21 but normal XX (female) or XY (male) on their karyotype.
  • Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome(Option D):patients are macrosomia, macroglossia, and often hypoglycemic at birth; they have a higher incidence of Wilms tumour.

questions.text: A child with short stature underwent karyotyping and the following was seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The karyotype shows 45 chromosomes,with a single X chromosome and no Y chromosome. This suggests a diagnosis of Turner Syndrome, with a genotype of 45, XO.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with distinctive facial features including a round face, thick upper lip, full cheeks, stellate iris pattern, and strabismus. On cardiac auscultation, you hear a harsh, systolic ejection murmur best heard in the right upper sternal border. Echocardiography later confirms supravalvular aortic stenosis. He is described as a cheerful child who interacts well with others. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The findings are suggestive of Williams Syndrome
    • Facial features, iris changes and especially Supravalvular AS are strong pointers.
  • Mental retardation and learning difficulties are, to a certain degree, associated with all affected individuals.
  • They have a very friendly personality, often called Cocktail Personality.

questions.text: Identify the likely diagnosis by looking at the karyotype?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • As seen in the karyotype, there is a partial deletion at short arm of chromosome 5.
  • 5p deletion (5p-) produces a syndrome called as Cri-du-chat Syndrome.
  • The main features are hypotonia, short stature, characteristic shrill cry in the first few weeks of life (also called cat's cry syndrome), microcephaly with protruding metopic suture, hypertelorism, bilateral epicanthic folds, high arched palate, wide and flat nasal bridge, and intellectual disability.

questions.text: A 2-day-old baby boy is admitted at the neonatal intensive care unit due to high fever with a temperature of 38°C and seizures. Physical examination reveals a newborn baby with wide-set eyes, small mandible, and a cleft palate. On auscultation of the heart, there is a holosystolic ejection murmur at the fourth intercostal space in the midclavicular line. Serum chemistries show severe hypocalcemia. This syndrome is caused by mutant genes found in which of the following chromosomes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the given clinical scenario the symptoms of facial dysmorphism, cleft palate, infection causing hospital admission, a likely heart disease and hypocalcemia. These findings together suggest a likely diagnosis of DiGeorge syndrome.
  • Its pathophysiology involves microdeletions of specific DNA sequences, called the DiGeorge chromosomal region (DGCR), from chromosome 22q11.2.
  • DiGeorge syndrome has characteristic features which include cardiac abnormalities, abnormal facies, cleft palate. The failure of development of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches leads to hypoplasia or aplasia of the thymus and parathyroid glands, causing cellular immunodeficiency and neonatal hypocalcemia .
  • It is often called the CATCH22 syndrome because of its characteristic manifestations.
  • Patients with partial DiGeorge syndrome may grow normally but patients who have complete DiGeorge syndrome have a very low immunity and increased susceptibility to infections even with common pathogens.
  • Timely diagnosis is critical since the disease is fatal without treatment.

questions.text: Single gene defect causing multiple unrelated problems?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pleiotropy refers to the phenomenon whereby a single mutant allele can have widespread effects or expression in different tissues or organ systems. In other words, an allele may produce more than one effect on the phenotype.
  • For example, Marfan syndrome has manifestations in different organ systems (skeletal, cardiac, ophthalmologic, etc) due to a single mutation within the fibrillin gene.

Explanation of other options:

  • Pseudo-dominance(Option B): Appears when a recessive trait is expressed in a heterozygote because the other allele is deleted or also mutated.Often seen in consanguinity or hemizygous deletions.
  • Penetrance(Option C): It refers to the proportion of individuals with a particular genotype who actually express the phenotype. Can be complete (100%) or incomplete.
  • Anticipation(Option D): It involves increasing severity or earlier onset of a genetic disorder in successive generations. Common in trinucleotide repeat disorders like Huntington's or myotonic dystrophy.

questions.text: Which among the following disorders is an example of polygenic inheritance?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cleft lip/palate shows polygenic/multifactorial inheritance.
  • Fragile X syndrome and G6PD deficiency show X linked recessive, whereas Cystic fibrosis shows Autosomal recessive inheritance. (Option A,B &C ruled out).
  • Certain birth defects and common conditions arise from the interaction of multiple genes and environmental influences, rather than following simple Mendelian patterns. Examples include:
    • Neural tube defects (e.g. spina bifida, anencephaly)
    • Congenital heart defects
    • Type 2 diabetes mellitus: influenced by numerous susceptibility genes and lifestyle/environmental factors
    • Human traits such as height and skin colour (continuous variation from many genes)

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought for evaluation due to concerns of short stature. Her height is below the 3rd percentile. Blood pressure is 130/92 mmHg in both upper limbs, and a radio-femoral delay is noted. On abdominal examination, a midline abdominal mass is palpable and a systolic murmur is heard on precordial auscultation. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present on general examination?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient in the scenario has short stature, hypertension, non-pitting edema on limbs suggesting lymphedema and examination findings consistent with coarctation of the aorta (HTN + Radio-femoral delay). All these are suggestive of Turner Syndrome.
  • Both bicuspid aortic valves andcoarctation of the aorta are common among individuals with Turner syndrome.
  • Bicuspid aortic valves occur in up to 50% of patients with Turner syndrome while coarctation of aorta occurs in up to 20% of cases.
  • Physical findings in patients with Turner syndrome include nonpitting edema of the lower extremities, wide spaced nipples and webbing of neck.(Option D ruled out)
  • Up-slanting palpebral fissures is typically seen in Down syndrome (trisomy 21), not Turner syndrome(Option B ruled out).

choices.text: Mosaic Down syndrome represents ~95% of cases and always runs in families
Robertsonian translocation accounts for approximately 3-4% of cases and may be inherited from a carrier parent
Nondisjunction-related Down syndrome shows decreased risk with increasing maternal age
All Down syndrome cases arise from balanced inherited translocations

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the genetic mechanisms and inheritance risk of Down syndrome is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Down syndrome is due in ~95% of cases to maternal nondisjunction (trisomy 21), ~3-4% are due to Robertsonian translocations some of which are inherited from a carrier parent and ~1-2% arise from mosaicism, which is typically sporadic.(Options A & Option C ruled out)
  • Risk of Down Syndrome is increased with increasing maternal age, due to increased chances of meiotic non-disjunction with age.The risk increases with maternal age, especially beyond 35 years, due to meiotic errors occurring during oogenesis .(Option D ruled out )

questions.text: A young male child presents with developmental delay and autistic behaviors. On physical examination, he is noted to have a large head (macrocephaly), prominent ears, elongated face with a prominent jaw, and enlarged testes (macroorchidism). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The findings of large head, large ears, large jaw and large testes (macro-orchidism) are suggestive of Fragile X Syndrome.
  • More commonly seen in boys, it is considered to be a trinucleotide repeat disorder
  • Alleles with 55-200 CGG repeats in the FMR1 gene on chromosome X are classified as premutations, associated with FXTAS and FXPOI (Fragile X associated Tremor/Ataxia Syndrome (FXTAS) and Fragile X-associated Primary Ovarian Insufficiency (FXPOI)), whereas full mutation alleles (>200 repeats) result in Fragile X syndrome.
  • Other features include hyperextensible joints, increased risks of ADHD, Autism, Anxiety Disorders
  • Most patients have low IQ, indicating intellectual disability and delayed development milestones during childhood.

Explanation of other options:

  • Williams Syndrome(Option A): It is caused by microdeletion of 7q11.23 (includes the ELN gene)
  • Key features:
    • "Elfin" facial features (broad forehead, short nose, full cheeks)
    • Supravalvular aortic stenosis
    • Friendly, outgoing personality
    • Intellectual disability
    • Hypercalcemia in infancy
  • Rett Syndrome(Option B):Affects girls almost exclusively and is caused by MECP2 gene mutation.
  • Normal development for 6-18 months, followed by:
    • Loss of purposeful hand skills
    • Stereotyped hand movements (e.g., hand-wringing)
    • Loss of speech
    • Seizures
    • Breathing abnormalities
  • Down Syndrome (Trisomy 21)(Option D):Most common chromosomal cause of intellectual disability
  • Characteristic features:
    • Flat facial profile, upslanting palpebral fissures, epicanthal folds
    • Single palmar crease
    • Hypotonia, congenital heart defects (especially AVSD)

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy, above the 99th centile for height, with gynecomastia and small testes. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Tall for age boy, with gynecomastia and small testes is likely to have Klinefelter Syndrome.
  • The phenotype is male with 47XXY, with delayed development of secondary sexual character.
  • They usually have azoospermia and are infertile.
  • Key Clinical Features:
    • Tall stature (↑ limb length; eunuchoid body habitus)
    • Small, firm testes(hypergonadotropic hypogonadism: high FSH, high LH and low testosterone)
    • Gynecomastia
    • Delayed or incomplete puberty
    • Infertility (due to testicular atrophy and azoospermia)

Explanation of other options:

  • Williams Syndrome(Option A):It is caused by microdeletion of 7q11.23
  • Features: Elfin face, supravalvular aortic stenosis, hypercalcemia, outgoing personality
  • Cri-du-chat Syndrome(Option C):It is caused by deletion on chromosome 5p
  • Features: High-pitched cat-like cry in infancy, microcephaly, severe intellectual disability, hypotonia, low birth weight.Physical growth and development are impaired(short stature).Not associated with gynecomastia or tall stature
  • Cornelia de Lange Syndrome(Option D):Genetic disorder affecting multiple systemsFeatures: Short stature, intellectual disability, limb abnormalities, arched eyebrows, low-set ears

choices.text: Sparse eyebrows & scalp hair- Pallister Killian Syndrome

questions.text: Identify the incorrect match for an abnormality and the corresponding common syndrome where it is commonly seen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cystic Hygroma and lymphatic disorders are common in Turner syndrome, not in other aneuploidies.

Explanation of other options:

  • Brushfield Spots- Down Syndrome(Option B):Brushfield spots occur in iris in patients of Down Syndrome. They do not interfere with vision.
  • Sparse eyebrows & scalp hair- Pallister Killian Syndrome(Option C): Pallister Killian syndrome is caused by Tetrasomy 12p. Most such patients involve a mosaic genotype with isochromosome 12p found in cell lineages. Clinical features include Sparse anterior scalp hair (more so temporal region), eyebrows, and eyelashes; prominent forehead; chubby cheeks; long philtrum with thin upper lip and cupid-bow configuration; polydactyly; streaks of hyper- and hypopigmentation.
  • Missing ribs- Patau Syndrome(Option D): Thin posterior ribs or missing ribs are a relatively common feature of Patau Syndrome.

questions.text: An infant had refractory hypocalcemia in the first few weeks of life and was diagnosed with congenital hypoparathyroidism. The child was referred to a pediatric cardiologist for further evaluation and also evaluated for a microdeletion defect. Which other clinical manifestation will often be present in such a child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • An infant presents with refractory hypocalcemia due to congenital hypoparathyroidism, along with a congenital cardiac defect. Genetic testing reveals a microdeletion. The most likely diagnosis is DiGeorge Syndrome (22q11.2 deletion syndrome).
  • Thymic aplasia causes reduced T-lymphocytes and cellular type of primary immunodeficiency. Such patients predisposed to recurrent viral and fungal infections. Thus recurrent candidiasis is the likely manifestation to be found in such patients.
  • The classic triad :
    • 1. Cardiac anomalies (especially conotruncal defects like TOF, truncus arteriosus)
    • 2. Hypocalcemia due to congenital hypoparathyroidism
    • 3. Immunodeficiency due to thymic aplasia or hypoplasia

questions.text: Which of the following is not a microdeletion syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Noonan Syndrome is caused by single-gene mutations in the RAS/MAPK pathway genes, commonly PTPN11.Inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.
  • The common microdeletion syndromes include the following
    • Angelman Syndrome: 15q11-q13
    • Prader-Willi Syndrome: 15q11-q13
    • Williams Syndrome: 7q11.2
    • DiGeorge or Velocardiofacial Syndrome: 22q11.2
    • Cri-du-chat Syndrome: 5p15.2
    • Miller-Dieker Syndrome: 17p13.3
    • Rubenstein-Taybi Syndrome: 16p13.3

questions.text: A Child is having microcephaly, beaked nose, abnormal broad thumbs and toes. Name The Likely Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A child with microcephaly, a beaked nose, and broad thumbs and toes is most consistent with Rubinstein-Taybi Syndrome
  • A microdeletion syndrome with site of microdeletions at 16p13.3
  • Clinical Features include
    • Microcephaly
    • Ptosis
    • Baked nose with low-lying philtrum
    • Broad thumbs and large toes
    • Intellectual disability

questions.text: All of the following are common diseases in Turner Syndrome, except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most common heart defects in Turner syndrome patients are bicuspid aortic valves, coarctation of the aorta, aortic stenosis, and mitral valve prolapse. (Option B, Option C and Option D ruled out).
  • TOF is not described in most textbooks and is thus the answer by exclusion.

choices.text: It is caused by maternal uniparental disomy of chromosome 15.
It results from a mutation in the MECP2 gene on the X chromosome.
It is associated with trinucleotide (CGG) repeat expansion.
It involves paternal deletion or maternal uniparental disomy of chromosome 15.

questions.text:
A child presents with short stature, hypotonia, polyphagia leading to obesity, and hypogonadism.
Which of the following statements is true regarding the most likely syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The child's presentation is classic for Prader-Willi Syndrome (PWS), a genetic disorder involving imprinting errors on chromosome 15q11-q13.
  • Caused by:
    • Paternal deletion (≈70%)
    • Or Maternal uniparental disomy (≈25-30%) : both chromosome 15s come from the mother
  • Features:
    • Neonatal hypotonia
    • Feeding difficulties in infancy, followed by polyphagia and obesity
    • Short stature
    • Hypogonadism
    • Mild intellectual disability or behavioral problems

Explanation of other options:

  • Mutation in MECP2 gene(Option B): It is seen in Rett Syndrome, mainly affecting girls.Features include Regression of milestones, stereotypic hand-wringing, seizures
  • CGG repeat expansion(Option C): It is seen in Fragile X Syndrome and causes intellectual disability, large ears, macroorchidism.Not associated with polyphagia or obesity

questions.text: A Child is having macrocephaly, large hands and feet, low IQ, is tall for age, has hypertelorism, seizures and premature tooth eruption. The testicular size is normal and the child is often clumsy in his activities. Name the most likely genetic abnormality?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical picture is fitting into a diagnosis ofSotos Syndrome, previously called as Cerebral Gigantism. Sotos syndrome, characterized by childhood overgrowth, macrocephaly, distinctive facial appearance, and intellectual disability, is most commonly caused by microdeletion of the NSD1 gene (located on chromosome 5q35).
  • Key features include:
    • Overgrowth, macrocephaly, prominent forehead, prominence of extraaxial fluid spaces on brain imaging, large hands and feet, hypotonia, clumsiness, mental disabilities are common
    • As opposed to Fragile X syndrome(CGG repeats),large testes are not seen.
    • Premature tooth eruption seen in many patients

questions.text: A child with Trisomy 21 developed Transient Leukemia. Such patients are likely to show which additional genetic abnormalities?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In newborns with Down syndrome, Transient Myeloproliferative Disorder (TMD) occurs in approximately 10% and is driven by somatic mutations in the GATA1 gene, which acts together with constitutional trisomy 21 to produce proliferation of megakaryoblasts. GATA1 mutations are therefore the key additional genetic abnormality in these infants.
  • 20-30% of these patients tend to develop AML-M7 leukemia by 3 years of age.

Explanation of other options:

  • Mosaicism(Option A): Mosaic Down syndrome refers to having a mix of trisomic and normal cell lines it does not explain the development of TMD in a Trisomy 21 child.
  • APP gene deletion(Option B): The APP gene on chromosome 21 is associated with Alzheimer’s disease risk in Down syndrome but has no role in transient leukemia or TMD.
  • Genomic imprinting(Option D): Imprinting involves parent-of-origin effects on expression of specific genes, but it does not contribute to TMD development in Down syndrome.

questions.text: A child is born with bilateral microtia, coloboma of the lower eyelids, absent zygomata, micrognathia, and a high but intact palate. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The description is most consistent with Treacher Collins syndrome.
  • A symmetric facial anomaly with lower eyelid colobomas, bilateral microtia, hypoplastic zygomatic bones, and micrognathia strongly suggests Treacher Collins Syndrome.
  • Persons with Treacher Collins syndrome are typically cognitively normal, but they often have conductive hearing loss. These patients have malformations involving structures arising from 1st and 2nd branchial arches.

Explanation of other options:

  • Pierre Robin sequence (Option A): It is characterized by a triad of cleft palate, micrognathia and glossoptosis.
  • Smith Lemli Opitz syndrome(Option B): It is associated with cleft palate, micrognathia, short nose, ptosis, high square forehead, microcephaly, hypospadias, cryptorchidism, VSD, TOF, hypotonia, mental retardation, postaxial polydactyly, 2-3 toe syndactyly, and defect in cholesterol biosynthesis.
  • Goldenhar syndrome(Option C): Itis also associated with anomalies involving the head and neck. The phenotype includes hemifacial microsomia and anomalies of the pinna with associated deafness. Other findings include ear tags, vertebral anomalies, and Arnold- Chiari type I malformations (herniation of the cerebellum into the cervical spinal canal).

choices.text: Mosaics with additional Y chromosome material

questions.text: Prophylactic gonadectomy is indicated for which Turner Syndrome patients?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mosaicism involving the Y chromosome occurs in 5% cases of Turner Syndrome. They often have a genotype of 45,XO/46,XY.
  • Gonadoblastoma among Y-positive patients occurs in 7-10% of such patients.(Option A and B ruled out)
  • Therefore the recommendation is that prophylactic gonadectomy for streak gonads should be performed even in the absence of MRI or CT evidence of tumors.
  • The recommended timing of this procedure is at the time of diagnosis.

questions.text: A Child is having short stature, triangular face, frontal bossing, micrognathia and clinodactyly. Name The Likely Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A child with short stature, triangular face, frontal bossing, micrognathia, and clinodactyly most likely has Russell-Silver Syndrome, a growth disorder due to imprinting defects or uniparental disomy.
  • Russell Silver Syndrome, also called as Silver Russell Syndrome is a type of syndrome arising due to complex genetic mechanisms.
  • 50% of Silver-Russell patients have hypomethylation of H19 and IGF2
  • 10% cases arise to maternal uniparental disomy involving chromosome 7
  • Rare mechanisms are implicated in the other forms.
  • Features include triangular facies, IUGR, short stature, clinodactyly, small jaw, frontal bossing, GERD and severely reduced subcutaneous fat.

Explanation of other options:

  • Ellis-van Creveld Syndrome(Option A): A type of chondrodysplasa.
  • Features include:
    • Short limbs, postaxial polydactyly, nail and teeth dysplasia
    • Often has cardiac defects
    • Does not present with a triangular face or frontal bossing
  • Edward Syndrome (Trisomy 18)(Option B): The common feature include Micrognathia, clenched fists with overlapping fingers, rocker-bottom feet
  • Severe developmental delay, congenital heart defectsTriangular face and clinodactyly are not classical.Generally has poor prognosis.
  • Cri-du-chat Syndrome(Option D): It is caused by 5p deletion.
  • Features include:
    • High-pitched cat-like cry
    • Microcephaly, intellectual disability
    • Hypertelorism, low-set ears
    • Facial appearance differs from triangular shape with frontal bossing

questions.text: Anticipation phenomenon occurs in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Anticipation is a pattern of inheritance in which symptoms became manifest at earlier ages and with increasing severity as traits are passed to subsequent generations.
  • The genetic defect in myotonic muscular dystrophy is on chromosome 19 at the 19q13 locus.
  • It consists of an expansion of the DM gene that encodes a serine- threonine kinase (DMPK), with numerous repeats of the CTG codon.
  • Myotonic dystrophy often exhibits a pattern of anticipation in which each successive generation has a tendency to be more severely involved than the previous generation.
  • Anticipation Phenomenon is also seen in Fragile X Syndrome.
  • Duchenne's muscular dystrophy, Becker's muscular dystrophy and Limb girdle muscular dystrophy does not show anticipation phenomenon.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations is most definitive for confirming a prenatal diagnosis of Trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome) or Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Karyotyping from amniocentesis is the gold standard for confirming the diagnosis of chromosomal anomalies like Trisomy 13 or 18.
  • Cell-free fetal DNA (cffDNA) testing is a non-invasive screening test with high sensitivity/specificity but not diagnostic.(Option C ruled out )
  • Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and targeted ultrasonography are useful for screening and detecting physical anomalies (e.g., neural tube defects, cardiac defects), but cannot confirm the specific chromosomal disorder.(Option A and Option B ruled out)
